str.o: Show some information about how Pike is using the memory it has allocated. Mostly useful for developers.
Show information about which features and modules are available in the Pike this Roxen is using.
All memory caches have been flushed.
Jackdaws love my big sphinx of quartz.
Shows various information about the module thread locks in Roxen.
Module lock status : Accesses to all modules
Locked means that the access was done using a serializing lock since the module was not thread-safe, unlocked means that there was no need for a lock.

Locked accesses to a single module can inflict quite a severe performance degradation of the whole server, since a locked module will act as a bottleneck, blocking access for all other threads that want to access that module.
Show a list of all open files and network connections.
Force a reload of all configuration information from the configuration files.
Check which modules handles the path you enter in the form
There is no configuration available that matches this URL.

You might see the old process for a while in the process table when doing 'ps' or running 'top'. This is normal. Roxen waits for a while for all connections to finish, the process will go away after at most 15 minutes.
Shows a backtrace (stack) for each and every thread in Roxen.
This is only a problem if a significant percentage of the accesses are passed through non-threadsafe modules.
List all active FTP sessions and what files they are currently transferring.
There are currently no active FTP sessions.
Show information about the main memory cache in Roxen
Shows detailed process status on Solaris 2.5 and later.
The other part should be submitted to a certificate authority, such as Thawte or VeriSign. The certificate authority will return the signed certificate that need to run a secure server.

The other part is used to create a certificate. You can create a certificate yourself; this is not the recommended way to use SSL, and browsers will complain about not recognizing the entity that has signed the key (i.e. you). But a self-signed certificate is a lot better than nothing.
Keys smaller than %d bits are ridiculous.
Keys larger than %d bits would take too long to generate.
How large key do you want to generate?
The desired key size. This is a security parameter; larger keys gives better security, but it also makes connecting to the server a little slower.

The largest key that is publicly known to have been broken was 155 decimal digits, or 512 bits large. This effort required approximately 8000 MIPS-years.

A key 2048 bits large should be secure enough for most applications, but of course you can you use an even larger key if you so wish.
Where to store the file, may be relative to %s.
A filename in the real filesystem, where the secret key should be stored. This is the filename you enter in the 'Key file'-field when you configure an SSL listen port.

Your X.501 Distinguished Name consists of a chain of attributes and values, where each link in the chain defines more precisely who you are. Which attributes are necessary or useful depends on what you will use the certificate for, and which Certificate Authority you use. This page lets you specify the most useful attributes. If you leave a field blank, that attribute will be omitted from your name.

Although most browsers will accept 8 bit ISO 8859-1 characters in these fields, it can't be counted on. To be on the safe side, use only US-ASCII.
Your two-letter country code, for example GB (United Kingdom). This attribute is required.
The state where you are operating. VeriSign requires this attribute to be present for US and Canadian customers. Do not abbreviate.
The city or locality where you are registered. VeriSign requires that at least one of the locality and the state attributes are present. Do not abbreviate.
The organization name under which you are registered with some national or regional authority.
This attribute is optional, and there are no specific requirements on the value of this attribute.

This is the DNS name of your server (i.e. the host part of the URL).

Browsers will compare the URL they are connecting to with the Common Name in the server's certificate, and warn the user if they don't match.

Some Certificate Authorities allow wild cards in the Common Name. This means that you can have a certificate for *.roxen.com which will match all servers at Roxen.Thawte allows wild card certificates, while VeriSign does not.
For how long should the certificate be valid?
A certificate includes a validity period. How many days, from now, do you want the certificate to be valid?
Save the request in a file:
Generate a new RSA key pair...
Note that it is possible to have more than one certificate for the same key.
Generate a Certificate Signing Request and an RSA key...

An X.509 certificate associates a Common Name with a public key. Some certificate authorities support "extended certificates", defined in PKCS#10. An extended certificate may contain other useful information associated with the name and the key. This information is signed by the CA, together with the X.509 certificate.
An email address to be embedded in the certificate.
At last, you can add attributes to the Certificate Signing Request, which are meant for the Certificate Authority and are not included in the issued Certificate.
This password could be used if you ever want to revoke your certificate. Of course, this depends on the policy of your Certificate Authority.
This is your Certificate Signing Request.
Generate an RSA key and a Self Signed Certificate...
Generate an DSA key and a Self Signed Certificate...
In order to use the SSL on your server, you first have to create a random key pair. One part of the key is kept secret.
If you have more than one Roxen version installed in the same location, you can use this action to change the currently running version.
Shutting down and changing Roxen version

If you change to one these Roxen versions, you will not be able to change back from the administration interface, you will instead have to edit the file %O manually, shutdown the server, and execute %O again
Create a site template from a site configuration (deprecated).
Select configuration to base the template on.
Note that you will have to start the new server manually because you may have to answer a few questions for the new environment file.
Shows a text file containing a configuration summary, suitable for support purposes.
Show information about the installed licenses and their usage.
Upload a new Roxen license file.
The garbage collector freed %d of %d things (%d%%).
%d seconds since last garbage collection, %d%% of the interval is consumed.
Object(s) missing in object link list.
Number of objects changed during object walkthrough (probably due to automatic gc call) - the list below is not complete.
The object walkthrough visited %d of %d objects - the list below is not accurate.
Show some information about how much time has been spent in various functions. Mostly useful for developers.
Show some information about how how much time has been spent in requests. Mostly useful for developers.
NOTE: This information is only available if the server has been stared with <tt>-DPROFILE</tt>.
This information is only available if the pike binary has been compiled with <tt>--with-profiling</tt>.
Show information about the available patches and their status.
Failed to uninstall the patch. See the log below for details
Patch uninstalled successfully. See the log below for details
%d out of %d patches sucessfully uninstalled. See the log below for details.
The server needs to be restarted.
Would you like to do that now?
Failed to install the patch. See the log below for details
Patch successfully installed. See the log below for details
These are patches that are not currently installed; they are imported but not applied. They can be found in local/patches/.
Click on a patch for more information.
Click on a Patch for more information.

The configured maximum size %s is divided dynamically between the cache managers based on the usage for the last half hour. If the caches are not full then all free space is assigned to each one of them. They will shrink to the configured maximum size as they fill up.

Cost HR is the cost hit rate, i.e. every hit and miss is weighted with the cost for each entry according to the cost metric of the cache manager. Note that it uses the approximation that every cache miss is followed by the addition of a new cache entry.
The garbage collector has not run yet.
%d seconds since the last garbage collection. The following statistics are over approximately the last hour.
Time spent in the garbage collector:
Note that the garbage collector referred to here is not the same as the one for the Roxen memory cache. This is the low-level garbage collector used internally by the Pike interpreter.
Repeated action request ignored – server process ID is different.
Warning: The site templates generated by this action have multiple issues and might not produce a working or correctly configured site. YMMV. This action is deprecated.
RXP cluster import over HTTP failed..
Failed to remove the patch. See the log below for details
Fetch and import the latest patches from www.roxen.com
Or manually select a local file to upload:
You can upload either a single rxp file or a tar/tar.gz/tgz file containing multiple rxp files.
There is also a <tt>bin/rxnpatch</tt> command-line tool to manage patches, if you prefer a terminal over a web interface.
